body: Just to get a complete picture, what are py36-exclusive feature we could benefit from?

I think the most useful one is [syntax for variable annotations](https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.6.html#whatsnew36-pep526), which would be very nice for e.g. stateobject and generally type annotations in the codebase. Second, the [formatted string literals](https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.6.html#whatsnew36-pep498) are considerably nicer than `"" % ()` or `"".format()`. So no immediate needs, but generally I think those things are useful. 
Depending on what we do for the proxy core, we _may_ also want async generators, although I really have not looked into this that much.
What I'm noticing just now: https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.6.html#pep-487-simpler-customization-of-class-creation might be a good fit for our addon system.
There are other benefits - our type checking system has a bunch of 3.5 exceptions that could go away. Less tangibly, I often see transient errors in CI tests for 3.5, where 3.6 works consistently.

issue.title: Python 3.5 is dead -- long live Python 3.6!

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.title: Python3.6 and installation

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
Can you explain please how to run a new version of mitmproxy on Debian 9? When I run
"mitmproxy" I always get the error, that python 3.6 or higher must be installed, despite the fact that I've installed it. 

##### Any other comments? What have you tried so far?
1. Aliases for "python" and "python3" pointing to python3.6
2. update-alternatives switching to python3.6

3."python --version" says "Python 3.6.4"

4. Installing python 3.6 from sources and from testing repository
5. Installing mitmproxy from git
6. Installing mitmproxy via pip

##### System information
Debian-9-x86_64
Mitmproxy 4.0.3

issue.title: Roadmap to version 1.0
issue.body:
I would like to propose that we shortly release 0.14, which feature wise includes the handshake separation and the advice around HTTP/2 WebSockets. Then we wait ~3 months to see if there are any bugs or issues to fix (especially around the HTTP/2 part). Then I think we target the 0.15 release to drop Python 2 support (I'd like to add type hinting throughout). Then again wait ~3 months for any bugs or issues and then release version 1.0. Timing wise I see this as, 0.14 in a few weeks, 0.15 in June/July and 1.0 in October. 

This is based on my view that the project is roughly 1.0 ready, which I think is a shared view.

issue.title: Upgrade to Python 3.8+

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
similar to #2266

This issue tracks all roadblocks we need to overcome to make use of Python 3.8-exclusive features. There's not immediate need to upgrade right away, but it's useful to have an overview of what's left nonetheless.

### Windows
 Windows users can just install Python 3.8
 Windows Subsystem for Linux currently contains Ubuntu 20.04

### macOS
 Homebrew and the mitmproxy formulae will work just fine with Python 3.8 or 3.9
 macOS Catalina ships with Python 3.8.2

### Ubuntu
 Groovy 20.10 has Python 3.8.6
 Focal 20.04 LTS has Python 3.8.5
 Eoan 19.10 has Python 3.7.5
 Disco 19.04 has Python 3.7.3
 Cosmic 18.10 has Python 3.6.7
 Bionic 18.04 LTS has Python 3.6.9
 Artful 17.10 has Python 3.6.3
 Zesty 17.04 has Python 3.5.3
 Xenial 16.04 LTS has 3.5.1

### Debian
 Debian bullseye has Python 3.8.6 - **unreleased as of 2020-11-21**
 Debian 10 (buster) has Python 3.7.3
 Debian 9 (stretch) has Python 3.5.3

### Arch Linux
 rolling release: has Python 3.8.6 as _python_ package in _Extra_

### Fedora
 Fedora 32 has Python 3.8.6 (released 2020-10)
 Fedora 32 has Python 3.8.6 (released 2020-04)
 Fedora 31 has Python 3.7.9
...
 Fedora 27 has Python 3.6.3
 Fedora 26 has Python 3.6.3
 Fedora 25 has Python 3.5.4

### Kali Linux
 kali-rolling has Python 3.8.6 (as of 2020-11-21) - rolling release since January 2016

### PyInstaller
 PyInstaller supports Python 3.8 since PyInstaller 4.1.
